## Method for producing the PUF-IRS crosswalk table, and how to interpret it

The PUF-IRS crosswalk table shows, for each of several tax-related concepts:

- the 2015 PUF variable name

- for both 2015 and 2021:

  - the location of a published counterpart in an IRS spreadsheet or any calculations needed to produce the counterpart

  - the location on tax forms

  - IRS totals for the variable

- relevant notes or known issues.

Not all elements of the table are completed yet. Note that some IRS variables can be found in multiple spreadsheets but the crosswalk table only gives the name of the spreadsheet this project uses.

### An example

The screenshot below shows the table row for salaries and wages.

The “PUF 2015 correspondence” column shows three blocks of information:

- e00200, the PUF variable name for salaries and wages

- The IRS filenames and cell address for the published data corresponding to e00200 in 2015 and 2021:

  - The 2015 file is 15in14ar.xls is the name of the main IRS file we use for wages in 2015. It follows a standard IRS naming convention: 15=2015, in=individual income tax, 14=IRS Table 1.4, ar=All returns.

  - The 2021 file is 21in14ar.xls. Per the links above, the files can be found from the [main IRS landing page for tables](https://www.irs.gov/statistics/soi-tax-stats-individual-statistical-tables-by-size-of-adjusted-gross-income), or in a [project Google Drive folder](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1CyDqUyhz8tFIIEufCW04PNUfA2SlFspf?usp=drive_link) (helpful in case the IRS changes file locations).

  - In each year, total salaries and wages were in cell G9.

The “IRS totals” column shows total salaries and wages reported by the IRS in 2015 and 2019 -- the amounts in cell G9 of the file for each year, as shown below:

![](images/paste-34.png)

The screenshot below shows that cell G9 in 2021 contains \$9,022.353 billion. Note also that rows below row 9 contain a breakdown by AGI range, and the column to the left contains the number of tax filers who had nonzero wages in 2021. This is the usual layout of IRS tables for most variables, although there are exceptions. Thus, if targeting or examining not just the amount of total wages, but numbers of returns with wages, and values by AGI range, we would examine rows below row G, and the column to the left (F).

### How do we know cell G9 in 2015 and corresponds to 2015 PUF variable e00200 and IRS Form 1040 line 1?

To determine correspondence, first we examine IRS reports for 2015 and compare them to PUF information for 2015. Then, where possible we confirm that definitions are the same for 2021 as for 2015. Finally, adjust as needed.

#### 2015 correspondence between PUF and IRS reports

We determine 2015 correspondence by comparing values from the Full SOI Individual Sample as reported in 2015 PUF documentation with IRS-published values reported in an IRS spreadsheet for 2015. We also compare PUF definitions to definitions used for IRS reporting.

#### Comparing values

The 2015 PUF documentation contains a table starting on page 46 that gives for each variable the amount in the 2015 Full SOI individual Sample (which we do not have access to) -- the data that IRS uses for published totals. The screenshot below, from the PUF documentation table, shows that total wages in 2015 from the IRS Full SOI sample were \$7.112 trillion. (The table also shows the amount in the 2015 Public Use Sample, available to us, is \$7.156 trillion, quite close to the full sample. In theory, we can reproduce this number by summarizing the full PUF. CAUTION: The page 46 table gives the total PUF amount, including the values on the four aggregate records, which, at present, we are not using in our PolicyEngine-PUF data file.)

Next we examine the IRS-reported total for 2015, in IRS Table 1.4 for 2015 (15in14ar.xls), which coincidentally is in cell G9, the same location as in 2021 (this will not always be the case ). The numbers match -- reported total salaries and wages also are \$7.112 trillion:

![](images/paste-35.png)

![](images/paste-36.png)

#### Comparing definitions

In some cases, we also compare definitions. The 2015 PUF documentation, on p.6, defines e00200 as “Salaries and wages,” and page A-2 shows that e00200 comes from line 7 of 2015 Form 1040:

![](images/paste-37.png)

Publication 1304 for 2015, Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report: 2015, p.196 says that what IRS tables refer to as Salaries and Wages also come from line 7, Form 1040:

![](images/paste-38.png)

#### 2015 Conclusion

At this point, we have pretty good evidence that PUF e00200 corresponds to IRS Salaries and Wages in 2015, and is reported on line 7 of 2015 Form 1040.

#### 2021

In 2021 we don’t have any new PUF values. However, we have to see whether IRS reporting definitions have changed, or values have changed in unbelievable ways. 

First, we look at the definition of Salaries and Wages, found on p.328 of Publication 1304 for 2021; an excerpt from 2021 Form 1040 is to the right. The definition looks to be essentially the same, but now the data are reported on Form 1040 line 1 instead of line 7:

![](images/paste-39.png)

Next, we look for an unbroken time series of salaries and wages. We find this by piecing together a time series from Publications 1304 for 2019 and 2021, being sure to look at current dollars in all cases. Here is the time series found in Table A in 2019 - it starts with the familiar \$7.112 trillion in 2015, increases to \$7.578 trillion in 2017, and ends with \$8.273 trillion in 2019:

![](images/paste-40.png)

We follow that with the comparable time series from the 2021 Publication 1304: We see \$7.578 trillion for 2017 and end with \$9.022 trillion in 2021. So we want to find \$9.022 trillion in relevant IRS spreadsheets.

![](images/paste-41.png)

Finally, we look at the relevant IRS spreadsheet and see the familiar \$9.022 trillion in cell G9:

![](images/paste-42.png)

Taken together, this is pretty good evidence that IRS Table 1.4 in 2021 (21in14ar.xls) cell G9 is our 2021 counterpart to the PUF 2015 variable e00200.

## Specific variables

### Salaries and wages

The key issue is whether salaries and wages are before or after subtracting contributions to retirement plans:

- PUF variable e00200 is from Form 1040 Line 7, which is generally from W-2 box 1, which is AFTER subtracting retirement contributions.

- IRS data for 2021 Table 1.4 are from Form 1040 Line 1, which is the counterpart to 2015’s line 1.

Thus, both PUF and IRS are AFTER subtracting contributions to retirement plans.

Form 1040 line 7. Main [2015 instructions](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Cyuo9NZ8NtL9CD0DDnZgYfXF1m3CzDsa/view?usp=drive_link) say, “Enter the total of your wages, salaries, tips, etc. If a joint return, also include your spouse's income. For most people, the amount to enter on this line should be shown in box 1 of their Form(s) W-2.” [Employer instructions](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1D8Egji5MFdKwp53OPpbEVEQDn71CjT5y/view?usp=drive_link) say, “do not include elective deferrals (such as employee contributions to a section 401(k) or 403(b) plan) except section 501(c) (18) contributions.”

**Note that W-2 box 1 is AFTER subtracting contributions to retirement plans.**

![](images/paste-44.png)

### Capital gains

#### PUF

- e01000 is called “Net capital gain or loss (+/-)”. e01000 is included on Form 1040 Line 13, and appears to be pulled from Schedule D. (See 1040 excerpt)

- e01100 is “Capital gain distributions reported on Form 1040”. For 1040A filers it is separately reported on line 10; for 1040 filers, it is included in line 13. (See 1040A excerpt; PUF documentation excerpt)

- Per documentation, weighted sum in PUF of e01000 in 2015 was \$701.379 billion and weighted sum of e01100 was \$11.767 billion. Combined sum of e01000 and e01100 in 2015 was \$713.146 billion. It is possible to calculate from the PUF the sums of positive and negative amounts for each, as well as numbers of filers with positive and negative amounts. (PUF documentation excerpt)

#### IRS

- Table 1.4 reports capital gain distributions reported on Form 1040. 2015 total of \$11.563 billion is the same as the full SOI sample, and is close to \$11.767 billion PUF e01100.

- Taxable net gains on Table 1.4 were \$713.598 billion and taxable net losses were \$18.646 billion. The net of these two was \$694.952 billion (713.598 - 18.646). This is the same as the full SOI sample and is close to the PUF sum of \$701.379 billion (PUF sum is 0.9% higher).

## Total income tax

### IRS

IRS spreadsheets define taxable returns based on what they call “Total income tax”. Here is the 2020 definition of total income tax, from the 2020 Publication 1304 (p.24), emphasis added:

![](images/paste-55.png)

Total income tax, as presented in these statistics, is the sum of income tax after credits (including the subtraction of refundable credits such as the EIC, American opportunity credit, net premium tax credit, and regulated investment company credit) plus the net investment income tax and tax on accumulation distribution of trusts from Form 4970 and is limited to zero (it cannot be negative). This calculation does not account for the impact of refundable credits, which have the potential effect of creating a negative tax liability for some taxpayers. This was accounted for by subtracting the portion of refundable credits that offset all other taxes and the refundable portion of credits from total income tax. Total income tax minus refundable credits increased 7.2 percent to \$1.6 trillion for 2020 (Figure E).

IRS defines total income tax more formally in the glossary on p.321. They say clearly here that total income tax is what they use to define taxable returns:

![](images/paste-56.png)

(line 24, Form 1040—any excess advance premium tax credit (APTC) repayment on line 2, Schedule 2, + any Net Investment Income Tax on line 8b, Schedule 2, + any Form 4970 tax on line 8c, Schedule 2 - line 27, Form 1040 - line 28, Form 1040 - line 29, Form 1040 - line 12a, Schedule 3 - line 12c, Schedule 3 - portion on line 12d, Schedule 3, related to tax on repatriated income, limited to zero.) “Total income tax” was the sum of income tax after credits (including the subtraction of the excess APTC repayment, earned income credit, additional child tax credit, American opportunity credit, regulated investment company credit, health coverage credit, recovery rebate credit, and qualified sick and family leave credit) less any deferred tax on repatriated (965) income plus the Net Investment Income Tax from Form 8960 and the tax from Form 4970. It did not include any of the other taxes that made up total tax liability. Total income tax was the basis for classifying returns as taxable or nontaxable.
